Message.Msg: Important Deals (1) Form 8-K for LOCAL CORP 7-Oct-2013 Entry into a Material Definitive Agreement, Financial Statements and Exhibits Item 1.01 Entry into a Material Definitive Agreement. On October 3, 2013, the Registrant entered into Amendment Number Six (the "Google Amendment") to that certain Google Services Agreement with Google Inc. dated June 30, 2011, as amended by Amendment Number 1, dated December 1, 2011, Amendment Number 2, dated February 1, 2012, Amendment Number 3, dated May 1, 2012, Amendment Number 4, dated June 1, 2012, and Amendment Number 5, dated June 21, 2013 (the "Google Agreement"). The Google Amendment provides for an extension of the Google Agreement until September 30, 2015. Google maintains very strict standards with respect to the display of Google's pay-per-click advertising and the Registrant must continue to meet those standards pursuant to the terms of the Google Amendment and the Google Agreement in order to continue to display such Google pay-per-click advertisements. The effective date of the Google Amendment is October 1, 2013. The foregoing description of the Google Amendment is qualified in its entirety by reference to the full text of the Google Amendment which is filed as Exhibit 10.1 with portions omitted and filed separately with the Securities and Exchange Commission pursuant to a request for confidential treatment. Exhibit 10.1 is a redacted copy of the Google Amendment and is incorporated herein by reference. Item 9.01 Financial Statements and Exhibits. Exhibit 10.1(1) Amendment Number Six to Google Services Agreement dated October 3, 2013 by and between the Registrant and Google Inc.

Message.Title: Try Again
Message.Msg: " we were building a - what I thought was a fantastic company. We had great people. We were changing - we were changing the way the marketplace operated" Wrong again. It was Jeff Skilling.

I read the businessweek article yesterday and was reminded of enron as well. Two things stood out. First, some employees describe the culture as a gladiator culture. Secondly managers that have 50 or more folks under them, have to "rank and yank", meaning the bottom performers are fired. Both are straight out of the enron playbook. When you have highly talented and competitive people that need to produce at all cost, reckless risks are often the results and some people will do unethical things to get results.

Topic.Title: Tech, insulting sybby's intelligence aint gonna save you from yourself

Message.Msg: Sybs: Not really intended to insult your intelligence. My point is that markets are not monolithic. Within any sector, some make money and some lose. It depends upon many things. Owning land in Detroit hasn't been a good thing. Owning it in North dakota has. You've torn into the idea of me investing in energy related companies, essentially calling it stupid and flawed, based upon a high level belief that energy markets have peaked (based upon fracking spreading). I'm not going to rehash, but there are many reasons to believe that certain forms of energy with continue to gain in nominal, of not real, terms while other assets classes get hammered. By the way, food is also energy dependent (much of the yield improvement has come from increasing energy intensity of production). And, for large part of the world, water will increasingly be as well... Happy to have you lecture me on options and trading. But, at the least, you should know by now I do my homework on fundamentals. Sure, if we have a collapse in financial assets, energy will get hit as it did in 2008. But unlike then, oil won't head into the 30's. All the tight oil players will be well before that...

Message.Title: Tech, your blinded by bliss.... Energy build out 2010-2015 = fiber optic broadband telecom buildout of '95-2000
Message.Msg: Looking back from 2008 with the advent of smartphonez, social media, and streaming data, the broad band buildout waz found to be correct, but only after the all went bankrupt from 2000-2003. Whether you like it or not, sybil knowz two thingz very well: 1. The energy industry both domestic and global 2. The bit coin financial markets and the leverage contained within them. Keep lying to yourself and keep losing coin hand over fist.... Or bail and save yourself with what you have left. Either way iz of no matter or consequence to sybil. Sybs iz only here to help a nice guy thats too focused on the engineering of 'what should be'. Sybil can tell that you have an engineering / technical back ground, and for that reason alone you will be murdered by your own mioptic aptitude and failer to see the bigger picture.

MCI had a very similar revenue based business model to Amazon. As i understand the scheme.......MCI would sell an expensive circuit, and buy an expensive circuit from the customer/CLEC, cause the guy they were selling to didn't actually need the circuit and never had any intention of paying for it. They'd show lots of revenue but lose money on every transaction. There was very little real traffic, just lots of keep alive data on circuits that were bogus. Tons of revenue growth but real loses on every transaction as they built out network gear that set there and depreciated. anyway I heard Amazon is scouting for Telecommunications personnel to build some network infrastructure.... is history gonna repeat itself?

Topic.Title: Tech, your blinded by bliss.... Energy build out 2010-2015 = fiber optic broadband telecom buildout of '95-2000

Message.Msg: I appreciate the concern. And, despite what may seem to be the case, I am willing to change my point of view as the FUNDAMENTAL facts / unit economics change. Energy and bandwidth are rather different of course. One is necessary for survival. One is not. One has nearly monotonically increasing unit costs while the other has experienced exponentially decreasing unit cost. One is inherently digital while another analog. SInce you know 1 so well, you will well know if shape of the net increase in global production versus investment in production curve... You must also understand the wildly different cost structure for tight/oil fracking versus offshore/deep sea or artic production. And, of course, as Cash alluded to earlier, surely you have modeled the population (all those Baby Boomers not going away anytime soon) over time and net energy consumption per capita as a function of national wealth (cross sectional analysis to better predict international demand effects)... Lastly, I'm not investing in primary energy production Sybs. That's not where the opportunity lies... You are accurate in your assessment that I am focused on what should be not what is. I despise the markets as they currently function. Not only do they no longer add value, due to the incessant "pain trade" (all driven by HFT/algo scalping aided by infinite leverage of TBTF/PD/POMO) the market is constantly sending value destroying "market" signals. As Cash said in a prior post, I should trade more actively to make money. But, my primary focus in on trying to do things that CREATE value and capture a reasonable share of it, rather than capture value without creating any. That is my "mistake". When others too recognize that the way we change the system is too vote our values with our wallets (both as consumers and investors), the games will end. I am serious when I say that AAPL, GOOG, WMT, TGT and others should pull all business from any firm underwriter in AMZN's next offering.

FWIW, Google is MUCH better positioned to enter the Telecom space. Sybs refers to that bandwidth buildout that crashed. Google bought TONS of dark fiber for pennies on the $. It also bought MOT who has plenty of IP around whitespace management. When all the anti-trust attention turns to Amazon (and it is starting to get more interesting in Europe. AAPL will be arguing that the Koh perverted anti-trust law in her ruling as Amazon is the monopolist -- which is a reasonable POV. And, the new Jeff Bezos book account of the Quidsi deal should put everyone on alert to Amazon's true nature...), Google will be able to get more aggressive rolling out the balance of its strategy. Installed my Chromecast yesterday... Looks like Google will have a $35 top selling product into the holidays. Nice way to blunt Amazon Prime video (both by including Netflix while laying the groundwork for its own subscription service and maybe shopping delivery bundle). I'd like to see a Chromecast bundle for $79 with its own subscription (Google has plenty of resource to match or exceed AMZN's non exclusively licensed library) and free 2 day shipping. All the volume that it takes away from AMZN will hurt it big time this holiday season as it has massively ramped all fixed costs...

Topic.Title: techstrategy: FWIW: you're a fool if you listen to a buttplug clown such as Sybil: no matter what

Message.Msg: NAS: You are right in that I'm not trying to create a campaign to take Amazon down. If I was, I would be sending the analysis of what Amazon's model is doing to the revenue side of state pension funds across the board and highlighting that they are undermining their own sustainability by supporting a sales tax evader (which is why Amazon just built in Kenosha to serve Chicago and NJ to serve NY) and also enabling these games by putting money into financial institutions that are creating an artificially low cost of capital that enables an even more aggressively predatory loss leader model, which amplifies the adverse effect on their local tax bases as it causes businesses lacking access to Amazon's artificial cost of capital to lose sales and many to go out of business. The institutions are playing with OPM and using it against them... If the state pension funds got it and pulled funds from those institutions directly and indirectly enabling this scam, this scam would be done. Kaput. As I said, I'm focused on doing things that create real value. Trading doesn't. It redistributes that which has been created. I use Amazon as a lens to track the disconnect between underlying fundamentals and money/asset flows. And, I document things to test how my fundamental (not stock price related) predictions hold up versus what plays out because I am positioning for success in the real economy, not the financial one. You all can mock all you want. I'm playing for what comes next. I've been early and it has been painful. But, it is coming and I will be here to benefit when it does.

Jeff is counting on another offering (whether debt or equity) to provide the cash flow to continue the aggressively predatory loss leader strategy (see Quidsi move) while it loads more 3P and FBA content onto the platform, at which time it will raise prices on 3P and FBA until they cannot compete with Amazon 1P. Nothing anti-competitive to see here... Will continue until AAPL, GOOG, WMT, TGT and every major competitor pulls all their business from whichever firms underwrite the next scam offering (needing capital again after only 12 months or so from the last $3B offering, while losing money...). But, once they do, or once the state pension fund managers start pulling capital from those enabling the DOMESTIC tax evading Amazon (they all evade taxes on foreign profits), this all craters and hard....
